bibl.title: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Albert E. Truby, December 11, 1940

div1.p: Lambert claims that he should be recognized for his Yellow Fever Commission service. He discusses other nurses and doctors whom he believes were instrumental in the experiments but have not been recognized.

div1.head: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Albert E. Truby, December 11, 1940
div1.opener:
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Dec 11th 1940
4718 Woodlawn Ave
Chicago
General A E Truby
Dear Sir
div1.p:
It was not Dr Amador or any of the
other Doctors it was Dr Pinto who had
charge of the Hosp- while Dr Ames was sick
Senator Morris introduced a Bill for
the benefit of Dr Pinto, he wanted his
heroism when he risked his life caring “or
treating” yellow fever for the board recognized
The man who stayed with Dr Lezear
was Schwieger, he had yellow fever at
guanajay so he was immune schwieger
also worked on the May Carthwright case
he was sent to cienfuegos later an
he has often mentioned that he served
under your command at that place
Schwieger think that because he helped
take care of Dr Lazear who was a member
of the Board he is entitled to recognition
although he was an immune himself
I haven't seen the congressional
record this year so I don't know if
Mrs Ames have a bill in or not
but if she has, I hope to heaven
Dr Ames's work will be recognized
When Maj Stark released Dr Ames as
cured up at the Hosp Dr Ames came
down to see us at once, he did not
take a single day off to recuperate
I think Maj. Reed had told him that
things hasn't gone so good while he was
absent as when he were there, every-
one els took a vacation except Dr Ames
Dr Pinto was releaved and Dr Ames
took charge as before. The General mention
that the War Dept. is opposed to the recognition
of any one except of those who were inocculated
at Camp Lezear, four men, Dr Cook, England,
Hildebrand and Weatherwalk were not inocculated
they only slept in dirty clothing building but
they were paid at the time and later honored
If yellow fever had been contagious
I would have been more exposed to
the disease than the four combined.
Also that if Mrs Ames succeeds there might
be a chance for others like me, there can't
be any one els but me except of
course Mrs Gillen and Lathic and they
were immunes, I don't know if I am
right or not but I claim Andrus as
my patient also I knew what to do
in an emergency and they didn't
I have affidavits from every one of the
boys that I have been able to contact
except Moran he think Mrs Gillen took
care of him if Gillen had taken care
of him he should mention Lathic also
because they worked together on Andrus,
but he is mistaken in that just as
he is mistaken in the statement
that he was offered $500.00 for taking
part in the experiment Dr Ames
would not have lied to him, I
heard Moran was bragging that he was
AC
In to L
the only one who served the board
for nothing I don't blame him
for not taking $200.00 if he had
been offered $500.00 but he wasn't
I only wish the War Dept would
order those who claims to have nured
the experimental cases to go to Washington
“at their own expense” and lay their
cards on the table. On May 14th when
I appered before the Military affairs Com-
I told the Com. that I was not asking
for any compensation all I asked for
was to be recognized as the nurse for
the yellow fever Commission I was
the only one serving the board with-
out the inducement of extra pay
Dear General I hope you will not think
me preposterous if I say that the boards
success in some mesure depended on
Dr. Ames and in a small part to his man
friday
